text: In Greek mythology, Antiope or Antiopa (Ancient Greek: Ἀντιόπη derived from αντι anti "against, compared to, like" and οψ ops "voice" or means "confronting") may refer to the following * Antiope (Amazon), sister of Hippolyte, kidnapped by Theseus during Heracles' ninth labour.Pseudo- Apollodorus, Epitome 4.1.16 * Antiope, mother of Amphion by Zeus, associated with the mythology of Thebes, Greece.Homer, Odyssey 11.260 * Antiope, also called Antioche,Scholaist on Sophocles, Trachiniae 266 as cited in Hesiod, The Homeric Hymns, and Homerica, The Taking of Oechalia fr. 4 daughter of Pylon and wife of Eurytus.Apollonius of Rhodes, Argonautica 1.86 *Antiope, daughter of King Belus of Egypt and wife of her uncle King Agenor of Tyre.Scholia on Euripides, The Phoenician Women 5Tzetzes, Chiliades 7.19 * Antiope, nymph of Pieria and the mother, by Pierus, of the Pierides, nine sisters who challenged the muses and, on their defeat, were turned into birds.Cicero, De Natura Deorum 3.21 * Antiope, daughter of Aeolus, by whom Poseidon begot Boeotus and Hellen (Aeolus).Hyginus, Fabulae 157 She was also called ArneDiodorus Siculus, Bibliotheca historica 4.67.3 – 5 or Melanippe,Hyginus, Fabulae 186 in some accounts. * Antiope, consort of Helios and possible mother of Aeetes and Aloeus.Scholia ad Pindar, Olympian Ode 13.52Diophantus in scholia on Apollonius Rhodius, Argonautica, 3.242 * Antiope, daughter of Thespius who bore Heracles a son, Alopius.Pseudo-Apollodorus, Bibliotheca 2.7.8 * Antiope, wife of Laocoön. == Notes == == References == * Apollonius Rhodius, Argonautica translated by Robert Cooper Seaton (1853-1915), R.
